I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) cluster will support the green 
development of the Yangtze River Economic Belt (YREB) in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
It will (i) support research on enabling policies, regulations, and incentive mechanisms needed to 
achieve the environmental goals and objectives outlined for the YREB region; and (ii) undertake 
analytical work needed to design and implement demonstration projects.  
2.  The TA cluster subprojects were developed at the request of the Government of the PRC 
with the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) to support the strategic project 
investments of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for achieving targets outlined in the YREB 
development plan.1 The TA cluster subprojects were included in the country operations business 
plan for the PRC, 2018–2020.2 In addition, they are consistent with the focus of ADB’s Strategy 
2030 and its development agenda of supporting institutional reform and achieving environmentally 
sustainable growth,3 which are the strategic priorities of ADB’s assistance to the PRC.4 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Rural vitalization in the Yangtze River Economic Belt. Among the rural villages in the 
YREB, about 40% do not have garbage collection facilities and about 80% lack basic sewage 
treatment, contributing to poor environmental conditions. The environmental quality of these rural 
areas is further exacerbated by agriculture-related nonpoint source pollution from outdated 
production systems lacking effective waste management systems. Because of these concerns, 
the NDRC released guidelines on a rural vitalization strategy on 2 January 2018, identifying 
agriculture, farmers, and rural areas as major bottlenecks to achieving the PRC’s economic 
development and environmental restoration goals.5 Under the rural vitalization strategy, the PRC 
seeks to modernize agriculture and rural villages through a range of measures, including (i) 
building ecological villages; (ii) improving provision of basic public services (including rural 
sanitation, solid waste collection, and nonpoint source pollution control); and (iii) improving rural 
governance. These issues complement and are closely aligned with the goals in the YREB 
development plan and are the focus of the TA cluster, sharing common outcomes for ecological 
and environmental improvement (footnote 1). 
4.  Government strategy. The outline of the YREB development plan was released by the 
government in September 2016 to guide the future development of the YREB toward the goal of 
ecological restoration and green development (footnote 1). The outline prescribes the following 
environmental improvement targets by 2020: (i) over 75% of Yangtze River water meets the class 
III standard or above, compared with 68% in 2014; and (ii) forest coverage reaches 43.0%, 
compared with 41.3% in 2014.6 In February 2018, the Ministry of Finance issued a guidance 
document on establishing and improving a long-term mechanism for ecological compensation 
and protection in the YREB.7 This document outlines a clear framework for implementing eco-
compensation programs and is consistent with the objectives and goals of the TA cluster.

2 
5.  ADB strategy. ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC, 2016–2020,8 aligned with 
the PRC’s Thirteenth Five-Year Plan, 2016–2020, also supports the government’s reform agenda 
and the YREB targets by focusing on the following strategic priorities: (i) managing climate change 
and the environment; (ii) promoting regional cooperation and integration; (iii) supporting inclusive 
economic growth; (iv) fostering knowledge cooperation; and (v) supporting institutional and 
governance reform.9 
6.  ADB’s framework approach for the Yangtze River Economic Belt. ADB is playing a 
catalytic role by focusing its limited resources to work together with different YREB stakeholders 
to develop and promote innovative yet replicable approaches for scaling up in each of the 
strategically  selected  priority  areas  where  ADB  has  institutional  advantages.  ADB  and  the 
government have agreed to adopt a framework approach, providing about $2.0 billion of funding 
in the YREB during 2018–2020 to strategically program ADB’s lending support for development 
initiatives in the YREB with priority given to the following four areas: (i) ecosystem restoration, 
environmental protection, and water resources management; (ii) green and inclusive industrial 
transformation;  (iii)  construction  of  an  integrated  multimodal  transport  corridor;  and  (iv) 
institutional strengthening and policy reform. These priorities will complement each other to 
support the overall ecological restoration and protection of the YREB. The individual projects may 
be in one or more of the core operational sectors of ADB—environment, agriculture and natural 
resources, transport, energy, and urban development. 
7.  The TA cluster offers an additional avenue of strategic yet complementary support to 
planned ADB lending and nonlending assistance in the YREB. The themes of the four TA cluster 
subprojects (Appendix 2) cut across key strategic priority areas consistent with ADB’s YREB 
framework  approach,  addressing the  areas  of  (i)  ecosystem  restoration  and  environmental 
protection; and (ii) institutional strengthening and policy reform, including capacity building. In 
particular, eco-compensation has been identified by the government as an important innovative 
financing mechanism to address both ecosystem restoration and rural poverty reduction in the 
YREB.  ADB  is  also  co-leading  with  the  China  Council  for  International  Cooperation  on 
Environment and Development a 2-year special policy study on eco-compensation and green 
development institutional reform in the YREB during 2018–2019 to create an enabling policy 
framework for effective implementation of eco-compensation schemes. 
8.  The executing agencies associated with the TA cluster subprojects are closely involved in 
the key strategic areas under the YREB development plan and the rural vitalization strategy 
(footnotes 1 and 5). In Guizhou, situated in the upper Yangtze River catchment area, the Guizhou 
provincial government through the Guizhou Provincial Finance Department (subproject 1) is 
supporting the project activities that aim to protect and improve ecological and environmental 
processes critical to achieving the YREB development plan outcomes. The NDRC, through the 
Western  Region  Development  Department  (subproject  2)  and  the  Chongqing  Municipal 
Development and Reform Commission (subproject 3), is a key player in the project activities that 
support the design and implementation of eco-compensation and related incentive mechanisms 
aligned with ecological protection and environmental improvement outcomes under the YREB 
development  plan  and  the  rural  vitalization  strategy.  The  State  Forestry  and  Grassland 
Administration under the Ministry of Natural Resources (subproject 4) plays a significant role in 
the PRC’s ecological recovery initiatives.

3 
9.  Lessons. The TA cluster builds on ongoing and previous ADB-financed investments of 
over $10 billion in various sectors and provinces in the YREB during 2000–2015. Although many 
of ADB’s investment projects have successfully functioned as demonstration projects and have 
enabled scaling up of lessons to other regions of the PRC and Asia and the Pacific, opportunities 
remain for further improvement. Some ADB investments in the PRC have typically responded to 
the demands of individual provinces and municipalities as stand-alone interventions. In addition, 
coordination of projects across sectors and administrative boundaries in the YREB, mechanisms 
of learning, and replication of lessons could be further improved to maximize synergies, co-
benefits, and sustainability. 
10.  Strategic  fit.  The  TA  cluster  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  (i)  Environment  Operational 
Directions, 2013–2020, which  aim to help Asia and the Pacific transition to environmentally 
sustainable or green growth; and (ii) Strategy 2030 (footnote 3).10 The project is also in line with 
ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC, 2016–2020 in supporting the government’s goal 
cited in the PRC’s Thirteenth Five-Year Plan, 2016–2020, on balancing the role of government, 
society,  and  the  market  to  deliver  inclusive  and  environmentally  sustainable  development 
(footnotes 8 and 9). 
III.  JUSTIFICATION FOR CLUSTER MODALITY 
11.  A TA cluster modality was determined to be the most appropriate means of providing 
strategic and targeted support for the YREB development plan (footnote 1). Linked TA cluster 
subprojects  will  support  a  program  of  activities  covering  capacity  development  and  the 
development of enabling policies and regulatory frameworks, with the common objective of 
supporting the  implementation  of  demonstration  projects  aligned  with  targets  in the  YREB 
development plan. The TA cluster modality provides the flexibility to support emerging needs 
through the design of the TA cluster subprojects during TA implementation. Since the PRC has a 
TA framework agreement for the YREB and the TA cluster subprojects have been programmed 
as knowledge and support TA projects, the TA approach is more appropriate because greater 
knowledge sharing and cooperation can be achieved within the TA cluster.11 
IV.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLUSTER 
A.  Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
12.  The TA cluster is aligned with the following impact: green economic development and 
ecological protection in the YREB achieved (footnote 1).12 The TA cluster will have the following 
outcome:  design  and  implementation  of  eco-compensation  and  ecosystem  protection 
demonstration projects enhanced.13 The outputs of the TA cluster subprojects will also reflect the 
outputs of the overall TA cluster. 
 
13.  Output  1:  Enabling  environment  for  ecological  compensation  demonstration 
strengthened. Output 1 will support the development of policies, regulations, and incentive 
mechanisms needed to establish appropriate policy and institutional frameworks that will facilitate 
effective ecological restoration and environmental improvement demonstration projects in the

YREB. Output 1 will be delivered through the preparation of research reports, and findings will be 
shared through training programs under the TA cluster subprojects. 
14.  Output  2:  Capacity  on  integrating  poverty  reduction  targets  into  innovative 
financing  mechanisms  for  ecosystem  protection  enhanced.  Output  2  will  support  the 
strengthening of the project designers’ capacity to effectively undertake analytical assessments 
needed for designing comprehensive ecosystem protection demonstration projects. Output 2 will 
be delivered through the preparation of research reports, which will be disseminated through the 
TA cluster subprojects’ training programs. 
15.  Output 3: Knowledge on lessons and findings disseminated. Output 3 will support the 
preparation and publication of at least two knowledge products, including policy briefs and case 
study research reports, which will summarize the findings and facilitate the dissemination of key 
lessons as well as the design and delivery of targeted training programs and study tours.14 The 
TA cluster subprojects 2 and 3 (Appendix 2) will primarily contribute to this output. 
B.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA cluster is estimated to cost $1,700,000, of which $1,500,000 will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government 
and the TA cluster subprojects’ respective executing and implementing agencies will provide 
counterpart costs and services, which are estimated to account for 12% of the total TA cluster 
cost. Detailed cost estimates and financing arrangements will be presented in each TA cluster 
subproject proposal, which will be submitted for approval following approval of the TA cluster by 
end September 2018. Once the additional financing resources have been identified during TA 
implementation, they will be mobilized to support the TA cluster subprojects, as and when needed. 
17.  For  each  TA  cluster  subproject,  the  government  and  the  respective  executing  and 
implementing agencies will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
facilities, domestic transportation, provision of subject-related government data and studies for 
the TA consultants’ use, provision of meeting rooms, and other in-kind contributions. 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The  Environment,  Natural  Resources,  and  Agriculture  Division  of  ADB’s  East  Asia 
Department will administer the TA cluster. Each TA cluster subproject proposal will be submitted 
to the head of the department in accordance with the business process for knowledge and support 
TA  cluster  processing.15 Subproject  activities  will  start  only  after  approval.  The  indicative 
implementation arrangements and the executing and implementing agencies for the TA cluster 
subprojects are outlined in Table 1.

20.  Consulting services. International and national consultants will be engaged individually 
or through firms as and when needed in accordance with the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and the associated project administration instructions and/or the staff 
instructions on business processes for knowledge and support TA prior to the approval of each 
TA cluster subproject in consultation with the government. Output-based lump sum contracting 
will be adopted to minimize the administrative burden. Individual consultants will be recruited as 
needed to provide international and/or national consulting inputs. Firms will be recruited using 
quality- and cost-based selection with a 90:10 quality–cost ratio because of technical complexity. 
The estimated cost and requisite fields of expertise are indicative, and estimates will be finalized 
prior to the approval of each TA cluster subproject in consultation with the government during 
follow-up missions. 
V.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Policy Research on Ecological 
Protection  and  Rural  Vitalization  for  Supporting  Green  Development  in  the  Yangtze  River 
Economic Belt, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
